description:
Leptospira biflexa is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Leptospira. It is classified as a saprophytic leptospira, meaning it is a free-living organism that does not require a host to survive.

The serovar Patoc is a specific antigenic type within the species L. biflexa. Serovars are distinguished by the unique composition of the bacterial surface antigens.

The strain 'Patoc 1' is a specific isolate or laboratory strain of the Patoc serovar of L. biflexa. This strain was originally isolated from the environment and is commonly used in laboratory research and diagnostic testing for leptospirosis.

Leptospira biflexa serovar Patoc strain 'Patoc 1' is a spiral-shaped, motile bacterium that can be cultivated in artificial growth media. It is considered non-pathogenic to humans and animals, in contrast to the pathogenic Leptospira species that can cause the infectious disease leptospirosis.
